docs.lead_paragraph: Bones, once taken for granted, have become a major health issue now that so many Americans are living well into their 70's, 80's and beyond. For at least half of women and one in eight men, bones are not bearing up as well as they should to sustain an active, independent old age free of debilitating fractures. As a result, osteoporosis -- bones seriously weakened by mineral loss -- has become a household word, as familiar to most people as cholesterol. And the pharmaceutical industry, supplement makers and now food producers have responded with products intended to keep Americans from breaking apart before their time on earth is up.

headline.main: Growing Old, With the Bones in One Piece

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on osteoporosis, how to protect oneself against it and drugs that foster healthy bone growth; says habits of young Americans today portend future epidemic of osteoporosis that far exceeds today's problems; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When they fell in love, she was barely into her teens, and he wasn't much older. Some saw a star-crossed couple who found understanding, joy and maturity in each other's arms. Others saw impulsive kids whose reckless passion cut them off from family, friends and more appropriate interests, provoked mood swings, delinquent behavior and experimentation with drugs, and ended in tragedy. Romeo and Juliet's story is centuries old, but these two very different views of adolescent romance live on, often simultaneously, in the minds of bemused parents.

headline.main: Young Love: The Good, the Bad and the Educational

docs.abstract: Researchers studying teenage dating and romance find potentially positive effects as well as negative one for adolescence and adult relationships and well-being; says teenagers need adult supervision and rules, like curfews, and parents should be alert to signs that relationship is becoming too consuming, reduces other social contacts or incites jealousy and feelings of ownership and coercion; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In many ways, Ryan Nuckel is a typical student activist: he doesn't take drugs, he rarely drinks, and he is fueled by a nagging anger over the fact that there are haves and have-nots, oppressors and the oppressed. He and his fellow insurgents would never consider themselves a counterculture: Hippies turned on and dropped out. He doesn't want to drop out. He just wants change. For Mr. Nuckel, activism was a slow evolution, simmering under the surface until he arrived two years ago at New York University. He grew up in Babylon, a mostly white middle-class Long Island town, listening to the music of Radiohead and Nirvana and reading the speeches of Martin Luther King Jr. and anything by Kurt Vonnegut when the assignment was the Federalist Papers. His father is a general contractor and his mother works in a print shop. Both are Republicans.

headline.main: The Making of a Student Activist

docs.abstract: Article on activism on college campuses profiles Ryan Nuckel, who helps run progressive student group Students for Social Equality at New York University; organization, one of 308 registered with university's Office of Student Activities, has broad agenda of social concerns, with mission statement calling for alternatives to politics of 'conformity, selfish individualism and complacency;' photos (Education Life) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Novartis A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it would offer cards to low-income elderly Americans to provide discounts of 25 percent or more on the company's brand-name drugs. Novartis said the discounts would take effect in January. Those eligible will be people who are 65 or older and have incomes of $26,000 or less for single people and $35,000 for couples.

headline.main: Novartis Plans Drug Discount For Elderly

docs.abstract: Novartis AG, Swiss drug manufacturer, will offer cards to low-income elderly Americans to provide discounts of 25 percent or more, beginning in January 2002, on company's brand-name drugs; those eligible would be people 65 or older, with incomes of $26,000 or less for single people and $35,000 for couples (M)
